text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the official Vietnamese press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- The National Assembly adopted Vietnam's first trade law on Wednesday to meet requirements needed to join the World Trade Organization.

-- The government has decreed that judges, prosecutors and police officers through to executives of the Law Department will be held personally financially responsible for compensating victims of court decisions that are later overtuned on appeal.
-- Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet told U.S. Charge d'Affaires that the appointment of the United States' first ambassador to Vietnam illustrated the improvement in bilateral ties.
-- Construction projects with the involvement of foreign investors will not be required to obtain construction licences.
-- The Ministry of Planning and Investment is considering the withdrawal of the licence granted for a U.S company to build a $50 million hospital.
-- Vietnam has granted licences for 94 new foreign investment projects worth $1.1 billion so far this year.

-- The government has called for greater assistance to Vietnamese communities living abroad, including traditional music performances, the distribution of newspapers and special domestic airfares and hotel rates.
-- Vietnam sold 50 billion dong ($4.29 million) worth of one-year Treasury notes with an annual coupon of 12.0 percent at an auction on Wednesday.
-- The Australian government pledged $10 million to assist Vietnam in human resource development over the next five years.
-- The Ministry of Labour, Invalids and Social Affairs and Vietnam's Trade Union have set up nationwide teams to inspect the implementation of the labour code and trade union law.
